{{refimprove|date=February 2016}} {{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Mohammed bin Awad bin Laden | honorific_suffix = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = محمد بن عوض بن لادن | native_name_lang = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1908 | birth_place = [[Hadhramaut]] coast, [[Yemen Vilayet|Yemen]] | baptised = | death_date = 3 September 1967 (aged 58-59) | death_place = Oom, [['Asir Region]], [[Saudi Arabia]] | death_cause = Plane crash | body_discovered = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | monuments = | residence = | nationality = | other_names = | ethnicity = | citizenship = Saudi Arabia | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = | years_active = | era = | employer = | organization = | agent = | known_for = Founder of [[Saudi Binladin Group]] | notable_works = | style = | home_town = | salary = | net_worth = | height = | weight = | television = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = | denomination = | spouse = 22 wives | partner = | children = 56
including [[Osama bin Laden]]
[[Tarek bin Laden]]
[[Salem bin Laden]]
[[Bakr bin Laden]] | parents = | relatives = | callsign = | awards = | website = | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | signature = | signature_size = | signature_alt = | footnotes = }} '''Mohammed bin Awad bin Laden''' ({{lang-ar|محمد بن عوض بن لادن}}; 1908 – 3 September 1967) was a multi-millionaire Saudi businessman working primarily in the [[construction industry]]. He founded what is today the [[Saudi Binladin Group]] and became the wealthiest non-royal Saudi, establishing the wealth and prestige of the [[Bin Laden family]]. He was the father of [[Osama bin Laden]]. ==Life== Mohammed bin Awad bin Laden was born on the [[Hadhramaut]] coast of south [[Yemen]] in 1908 to Awad bin Aboud bin Laden, a [[Kindah|Kindite]] [[Hadhrami people|Hadhrami]] tribesman from al-Rubat, a village in Wadi Doan; Mohammed's paternal grandfather was Aboud bin Laden, the son of Ali bin Laden, one of four brothers (the others being Ahmed, Mansour, and Zaid) from whom the four [[bin Laden family|bin Laden]] clans trace their ancestry. His son [[Osama bin Laden]] was the notorious founder of [[al-Qaeda]], the [[Sunni]] [[militant Islamist]] organization. Poor and uneducated, Mohammed emigrated to [[Tihamah]] before [[World War I]], initially working as a porter in [[Jeddah]]. In 1930, he started his own construction business and after coming to the attention of [[Ibn Saud of Saudi Arabia|Abdul Aziz Ibn Saud]], first monarch of [[Saudi Arabia]], he eventually achieved such success that his family became known as "the wealthiest non-royal family in the kingdom." Mohammed bin Laden's enormous financial success was ascribed to a shrewd business sense, fealty to Saudi Arabia's rulers, reliability and a willingness to offer the lowest bid on construction contracts. As the "royal builder," Mohammed bin Laden forged close relationships with the royal family, particularly [[Faisal of Saudi Arabia|Prince Faisal]] of Saudi Arabia. In 1964, Prince Faisal deposed his half-brother, [[Saud of Saudi Arabia|King Saud]], and began rebuilding the kingdom after the wasteful excesses of the Saud era. King Faisal accepted Mohammed bin Laden's offer of financial assistance to support the national economy and as a reward, King Faisal issued a royal decree awarding all future construction projects to bin Laden's construction company. As a result, bin Laden's company eventually amassed assets in excess of US$5 billion. He made his initial fortune from exclusive rights to all mosque and other religious building construction in Saudi Arabia and several other Arab countries. Until 1967, Mohammed bin Laden held exclusive responsibility for restorations at the [[Al-Aqsa Mosque]] in [[Jerusalem]]. Despite his royal associations and great wealth, Mohammed bin Laden lived a relatively simple and devout life compared to many wealthy Saudis, demanding that his children observe a strict religious and moral code. In his later years, the bin Laden corporate network diversified its activities beyond construction, largely in foreign investment and oil. == Wives and children == He fathered a total of 56 children by 22 wives. Mohammed never had more than four wives at a time—divorcing older wives and marrying new ones as needed to limit the number of current wives to four and stay within the letter of [[Polygyny in Islam|Sunni Islam marriage law]]. According to [[Carmen bin Ladin]], Mohammed was planning to wed a 23rd wife the night he died, and was heading there when his plane crashed.{{Citation |last=Bin Laden |first=Carmen |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xPn-MbYyId8C |title=Inside the Kingdom: My Life in Saudi Arabia |publisher=Hachette Book Group |year=2005 |isbn=0-446-61694-X |pages=65–66}} His best known son is Osama bin Laden, the notorious founder of al-Qaeda, the Sunni militant Islamist organization. Osama bin Ladin’s mother, [[Hamida al-Attas]], was born and raised in Syria before marrying Bin Laden and moving to Saudi Arabia. She was Mohammed’s 11th wife. == Death == On 3 September 1967, Mohammed bin Laden was killed when his company airplane, a [[Beechcraft]], crashed during landing in Oom, [['Asir Province]], in southwest Saudi Arabia.The Bin Ladens – Steve Coll (Penguin, 2008), pp. 118–120. ==Legacy== Following Mohammed bin Laden's death, his eldest sons, principally [[Salem bin Laden]], renamed the organization, "Binladen Brothers for Contracting and Industry" and continued to expand their late father's company until it employed more than 40,000 people. Salem bin Laden was killed in the United States in 1988 when his ultralight aircraft collided with power lines.{{Cite web|title = Rags to riches story of the bin Laden family is woven with tragedy|url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/aug/01/rags-to-riches-story-of-the-bin-laden-family-is-woven-with-tragedy|website = the Guardian|accessdate = 2015-10-06|first = Jason|last = Burke}} Many members of the Bin Laden family have moved away from Saudi Arabia and settled in Europe and the US. In May 1990, the company was renamed the Saudi Binladin Group under the leadership of [[Bakr bin Laden]].{{Cite web|title = Mohammed bin Awad bin Laden|url = http://www.historycommons.org/entity.jsp?entity=mohammed_bin_awad_bin_laden_1|website = www.historycommons.org|accessdate = 2015-10-06}} The [[Saudi Binladin Group]] as it is now known, is involved in construction, engineering, manufacturing, and telecommunications. Construction projects include airports, housing complexes, tunnels, and bridges. The group is also involved in city planning and real estate development. The Saudi Binladin Group is Egypt's largest private foreign company and negotiated with the Lebanese government to rebuild part of central Beirut under a US $50 million contract. In 2009, the Bin Laden family was listed as the 5th wealthiest Saudi family by [[Forbes|Forbes magazine]], with a reported net worth of $7 billion.{{Cite web|title = The Five Richest Saudis|url = https://blogs.wsj.com/wealth/2009/08/31/the-five-richest-saudis/|website = WSJ Blogs - The Wealth Report|date = 2009-08-31|accessdate = 2015-10-06}} ==Descendants== [[Bin Laden family|Mohammed bin Awad bin Laden's sons]]: # [[Salem bin Laden]] (1946–1988) ''married'' [[Caroline Carey]] # Ali bin Laden # Thabet bin Laden (d. 2009) # Mahrous bin Laden # Hassan bin Laden # [[Bakr bin Laden]] # Khalid bin Laden # [[Yeslam bin Ladin]] (born 1950) ''married'' [[Carmen Dufour]] (born 1954) ## Wafah Dufour (born 1978) ## Najia Dufour (born 1979) ## Noor Dufour (born 1987) # Ghalib bin Laden # Yahya bin Laden # Abdul Aziz bin Laden # Issa bin Laden # Tarek bin Laden # Ahmed bin Laden # Ibrahim bin Laden # [[Shafiq bin Laden]] # [[Osama bin Laden]] (1957–2011) ''married'' [[Najwa Ghanem]] (born 1960) # Khalil bin Ladin # Saleh bin Ladin # Haider bin Laden # Saad bin Laden # Abdullah bin Laden # Yasser bin Laden # Mohammad bin Laden (born 1967) == References == {{reflist}} {{Osama bin Laden}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bin Laden, Mohammed}} [[Category:1909 births]] [[Category:1967 deaths]] [[Category:Bin Laden family|Mohammed]] [[Category:Saudi Arabian businesspeople]] [[Category:Victims of aviation accidents or incidents in Saudi Arabia]] [[Category:Yemeni emigrants to Saudi Arabia]]

{{Infobox building | name = Moscow International Business Center | native_name = Московский Международный Деловой Центр | image = Moscow-City (36211143494).jpg | image_size = 300px | caption = | alternate_names = Moscow City | status = | highest_prev = | highest_next = | highest_start = | highest_end = | address = | location_town = | location_country = | location = [[Presnensky District]], [[Moscow]], [[Russia]] | floor_count = | start_date = | completion_date = | opening = | management = PJSC City | owner = | roof = | architect = | engineer = | main_contractor = | module = {{Infobox street | embed = yes | metro = {{MOSMETRO-bull|4}} [[Mezhdunarodnaya (Moscow Metro)|Mezhdunarodnaya]]
{{MOSMETRO-bull|4}} [[Vystavochnaya]]
{{MOSMETRO-bull|8A}} [[Delovoy Tsentr (Kalininsko-Solntsevskaya Line)|Delovoy Tsentr]] {{small|(closed)}}
{{MOSMETRO-bull|11}} [[Delovoy Tsentr (Third Interchange Contour)|Delovoy Tsentr]]
{{MOSMETRO-bull|14}} [[Delovoy Tsentr (Moscow Central Circle)|Delovoy Tsentr]] }} }} The '''Moscow International Business Center''' ('''MIBC''') ({{lang-rus|Московский международный деловой центр|r=Moskovskiy mezhdunarodniy delovoy tsentr}}), also known as''' “Moscow City”''' ({{lang-rus|«Москва-Сити»|r="Moskva-Citi"}}),{{Cite web|url=http://www.citynext.ru|title=Official website |publisher=Eng.citynext.ru |date= |accessdate=25 September 2010}}{{Cite web |url=http://www.stroi.ru/eng/default.aspx?m=34&d=35 |title=Construction World: Integrated Body For Urban Design Policy And Development Of Moscow |publisher=Stroi.ru |date= |accessdate=25 September 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071015210813/http://stroi.ru/eng/default.aspx?m=34&d=35 |archivedate=15 October 2007 |df=dmy-all }} is a [[commercial district]] in central [[Moscow]], [[Russia]]. Located east of the [[Third Ring Road (Moscow)|Third Ring Road]] in the [[Presnensky District]] of the [[Central Administrative Okrug]], the MIBC is currently under development. Construction of the MIBC took place on the Presnenskaya Embankment next to the [[Moskva River]], approximately {{convert|4|km|mi|sp=us}} west of [[Red Square]], and just east of the Third Ring Road. The project occupies an area of 60 hectares, with the territory chosen being the only area in central Moscow that can accommodate such a project. The MIBC is expected to become the first zone in [[Russia]] to combine business activity, living space and entertainment in one single development.{{Cite web|url=http://www.citynext.ru/ |title=ОАО "СИТИ" – Москва-Сити – Московский международный деловой центр |publisher=Citynext.ru |date=14 September 2010 |accessdate=25 September 2010}} The Moscow government first conceived the project in 1992.{{Cite web|url=http://www.designbuild-network.com/projects/mibc/ |title=Moscow International Business Centre (MIBC), Moscow |publisher=Design Build Network |date= |accessdate=25 September 2010}} An estimated 250,000 – 300,000 people will be working in, living in, or visiting the complex at any given time. MIBC includes 6 skyscrapers with maximum height of 300 meters or more ([[List of tallest buildings in Shanghai|Shanghai has 5]], [[List of tallest buildings in Hong Kong|Hong Kong has 6]], [[List of tallest buildings in Chicago|Chicago has 6]], [[List of tallest buildings in New York City|New York has 8]]). Europe's second tallest building, the [[Federation Tower]], is in the MIBC. The complex also includes the [[OKO Tower|third-tallest]], [[Mercury City Tower|fourth-tallest]], [[Eurasia (building)|sixth-tallest]], [[City of Capitals|seventh-tallest]], and [[Naberezhnaya Tower|eighth-tallest]] buildings in [[Europe]]. By 2016 twelve of twenty-three planned facilities of MIBC were already built, seven buildings are in construction and four are in the design stage.{{cite web|url=http://tekstilschiky.mos.ru/presscenter/news/detail/3324736.html|title=«Москва-Сити» к 2018 году развернется на 100 га|website=tekstilschiky.mos.ru}} __TOC__ == History == Before construction began, the area had been an old [[stone quarry]] where most of the buildings were old factories and industrial complexes that had been closed or abandoned. In order to manage the project, a public company, CITY, was created in 1992 in order to oversee the initial creation and development of Moscow City as well as its subsequent usage. CITY is also a general contractor and both landlord and leaser. Overall responsibility for the [[Architectural plan|architectural planning]] and design of Moscow City belongs to the architectural studio No. 6, which is a part of the large Moscow practice Mosproject-2 named after Mikhail Vasilyevich Posokhin. This group, headed by Gennady Lvovich Sirota, who is officially the Chief Architect of Moscow City, is in charge of overseeing the design of the complex as a whole and agreeing the details of individual projects. Each building lot has its own investor and architect. By 2014 the volume of investments in Moscow City was approximately $12 billion.{{cite web|url=http://www.vedomosti.ru/newspaper/articles/2014/03/18/25-let-spustya|title=Анатомия проекта: 25 лет спустя|first=|last=Ведомости|date=18 March 2014|publisher=}} ==Layout== File:Moskva_city.svg|center|550px|The plots of Moscow-City poly 1641 833 1642 834 1680 899 1659 916 1779 1118 1798 1101 1843 1153 1780 1200 1739 1146 1757 1133 1638 928 1621 941 1582 869 [[Bagration Bridge]] poly 1173 482 1174 483 1395 379 1430 436 1220 562 [[Expocentre]] poly 1484 465 1485 466 1850 253 1818 182 1891 140 2106 507 1749 800 1674 792 [[Expocentre]] poly 1586 721 1587 722 1638 804 1566 845 1517 766 [[Evolution Tower]] poly 1512 770 1513 771 1620 952 1511 1022 1412 828 [[Evolution Tower]] poly 1407 832 1408 833 1512 1023 1399 1090 1288 900 [[Imperia Tower]] poly 1501 583 1502 583 1581 710 1451 783 1372 662 [[Central Core]] poly 1368 663 1369 664 1449 786 1287 883 1209 756 [[Central Core]] poly 1205 758 1206 759 1281 882 1143 963 1099 964 1060 930 1049 894 1056 860 1069 841 [[Central Core]] poly 1283 901 1284 902 1396 1094 1224 1170 1157 976 [[City of Capitals]] poly 1149 979 1150 980 1215 1172 1132 1193 1059 1192 996 1167 948 1129 973 1097 983 1097 1076 969 1107 984 1141 983 [[Naberezhnaya Tower]] poly 1017 720 1018 721 1066 812 1039 838 1027 877 846 874 843 818 [[Eurasia (building)]] poly 1196 613 1197 614 1248 697 1077 805 1030 713 [[Federation Tower]] poly 1319 518 1320 519 1381 621 1260 697 1232 650 1277 623 1241 566 [[Mercury City Tower]] poly 774 289 775 290 838 315 823 388 836 614 798 627 766 602 755 536 753 377 [[Northern Tower]] default [[File:Moskva_city.svg]] desc bottom-left {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; Foundation work. |- | rowspan="3" |9 |[[City of Capitals]]: Office building | rowspan="3" |2005 |2008 | colspan="3" |70 |17 | |- |City of Capitals: [[Saint Petersburg]] | rowspan="2" |2009 | colspan="3" |257 |65 | |- |City of Capitals: [[Moscow]] | colspan="3" |302 |73 | |- | rowspan="3" |10 |[[Naberezhnaya Tower|Naberezhnaya Tower A]] |2003 |2004 | colspan="3" |85 |17 | |- |Naberezhnaya Tower B |2004 |2005 | colspan="3" |127 |27 | |- |Naberezhnaya Tower C |2005 |2007 | colspan="3" |268 |59 | |- | rowspan="3" |11 |[[IQ-quarter]]: Tower 1 | rowspan="3" |2008 | rowspan="3" |2017 | colspan="3" |85 |22 | |- |IQ-quarter: Tower 2 | colspan="3" |141 |32 | |- |IQ-quarter: Tower 3 | colspan="3" |173 |42 | |- |12 |[[Eurasia (building)|Eurasia/Steel Peak]] |2007 |2015 | colspan="3" |309 |70 | |- | rowspan="2" |13 |[[Federation Tower]]s: Zapad |2003 |2008 | colspan="3" |242 |63 | |- |Federation Towers: Vostok |2004 |2017 | colspan="3" |374 |95 |The tallest completed building in EuropeCompleted part of complex: The Zapad Tower in use, The Vostok Tower is glazed |- |14 |[[Mercury City Tower]] |2009 |2013 | colspan="3" |339 |75 | |- |15 |Grand Tower |2013 |2019 |0 | colspan="2" |283 |50 | |- | rowspan="3" |16 |[[OKO]]: South Tower | rowspan="3" |2011 | rowspan="2" |2015 | colspan="3" |354 |85 | |- |OKO: North Tower | colspan="3" |245 |49 | |- |OKO: Parking |2017 | colspan="3" |59 |12 | |- | rowspan="2" |17–18 |[[Neva towers|Neva Tower 1]] | rowspan="2" |2013 | rowspan="2" |2019 |202 | colspan="2" |337 |77 |The construction of the 49th floor (on 18 October 2017) |- |Neva Tower 2 |0 | colspan="2" |290 |63 |Zero level (on 18 October 2017) |- |19 |[[Northern Tower]] |2005 |2007 |132 |108 |132Antenna |27 | |} == Management == Established in the spring of 1992, the [[Open joint-stock company|PJSC]] City Company manages the creation and development of the MIBC. On December 30, 1994, the [[Government of Moscow]] authorized PJSC City to act as the managing company for the MIBC and to negotiate with third parties to help develop the MIBC. As of February 2014, the company is owned by the Solvers Group led by Oleg Malis.{{Cite web|url=https://www.vedomosti.ru/newspaper/articles/2014/06/16/poslednie-kogo-zdes-zhdali-lyudi-kotorye-pridut-navodit|title="Последние, кого здесь ждали, - люди, которые придут наводить порядок", - Олег Малис, управляющий партнер группы Solvers|last=Ведомости|date=2014-06-16|access-date=2018-03-24}}{{Cite web|url=http://citymoscow.ru/about|title=ПАО «СИТИ» {{!}} Управляющая компания ММДЦ «Москва-Сити»|website=citymoscow.ru|access-date=2018-04-15}} ==Transport== === Pedestrian === The [[Bagration Bridge]] is a pedestrian bridge that goes over the [[Moskva River]]. It connects Tower 2000 and the rest of the MIBC complex. === Road === To correspond with the growing MIBC, new highways and interchanges were built to connect the MIBC with the main transport arteries of the city. These projects include the ten-lane Dorogomilovsky Bridge of the [[Third Ring Road (Moscow)|Third Ring Road]] over the [[Moskva River]], the Third Ring Road interchange with [[Kutuzovsky Prospekt|Kutuzovsky Avenue]], and the extension of the Presnenskaya Embankment. Existing roads were reconstructed and rearranged. Major thoroughfares that connect to the MIBC are the [[Third Ring Road (Moscow)|Third Ring Road]], 3rd Magistralnaya street, and the Presnenskaya Embankment. === Rapid transit === The MIBC is served by several [[Moscow Metro|metro]] stations, two of which are named Delovoy Tsentr ([[Russian language|Russian]] for business district). Stations [[Vystavochnaya]] (formerly known as Delovoy Tsentr) and [[Mezhdunarodnaya (Moscow Metro)|Mezhdunarodnaya]] opened on the [[Filyovskaya Line]] in 2005 and 2006 respectively, [[Delovoy Tsentr (Kalininsko–Solntsevskaya line)|Delovoy Tsentr]] on the [[Kalininsko–Solntsevskaya line|Kalininsko-Solntsevskaya Line]] in 2014, and a [[Delovoy Tsentr (Bolshaya Koltsevaya line)|second Delovoy Tsentr]] on the [[Bolshaya Koltsevaya line]] in 2017. The MIBC in addition is served by [[Moscow Central Circle]] with the station also named [[Delovoy Tsentr (Moscow Central Circle)|Delovoy Tsentr]] which opened in 2016. There are also plans to install a high-speed rail system between the MIBC and [[Sheremetyevo International Airport]]. {{center |{{Gallery |title= |width=200 | height= |align=center |footer= |File:Delovoj Centr MosMetro station 01-2015 with train.jpg |[[Delovoy Tsentr (Kalininsko-Solntsevskaya Line)|Delovoy Tsentr]] ([[Kalininsko–Solntsevskaya line]]) |File:Delovoy Tsentr.jpg |[[Delovoy Tsentr (Bolshaya Koltsevaya line)|Delovoy Tsentr]] ([[Bolshaya Koltsevaya line]]) |File:Mezhduarodnaya st.JPG |[[Mezhdunarodnaya (Moscow Metro)|Mezhdunarodnaya]] |File:Vystavochnaya station.jpg |[[Vystavochnaya]] |File:MCC Delovoy centr.jpg |[[Delovoy Tsentr (Moscow Ring Railway)|Delovoy Tsentr]] ([[Moscow Central Circle|MCC]]) |File:Interchange near Moscow-City.jpg |Transport interchange of [[Third Ring Road (Moscow)|Third Ring Road]] and 3rd Magistralnaya Street near the Moscow City. }} }} == Accidents == [[File:Pozhar federation-2012-04-02-(22-42).jpg|thumb|250x250px|Fire on the 67th floor of Vostok of the [[Federation Tower]]s (April 2, 2012).]] * On April 2, 2012, a fire occurred on the 67th floor of [[Federation Tower|Federation Tower East/Vostok]] while it was under construction. 25 fire-fighting units and 4 helicopters of the Moscow Aviation Center responded and took four hours to extinguish the fire. Nobody was injured.{{Cite web|url=http://positiverussia.com/news/2012/04/03/Pozhar-na-bashne-Vostok-kompleksa-Federaciya/|title=Пожар на башне "Восток" комплекса "Федерация"|website=positiverussia.com|access-date=2017-12-31}} * On January 25, 2013, a fire occurred on the 24th floor of one of the skyscrapers at the [[OKO]] complex while it was under construction.{{Cite news|url=https://www.pravda.ru/news/accidents/25-01-2013/1142834-fire-0/|title=В Москва-сити сгорел очередной небоскреб|date=2013-01-25|work=Правда.Ру|access-date=2017-12-31|language=ru}} * On January 12, 2014, a fire occurred on the 15th floor of a 17-story building on Testovaya Street while it was under construction. The fire was extinguished and nobody was injured.{{Cite news|url=https://ria.ru/incidents/20140112/988808920.html|title=Возгорание произошло в одном из строящихся зданий "Москва-сити"|last=|first=|date=2014-01-12|work=РИА Новости|access-date=2017-12-31|language=ru}} * On July 9, 2014, a fire occurred on [[Evolution Tower]]. The fire was extinguished and nobody was injured.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bfm.ru/news/264630|title=В одной из башен "Москва-Сити" произошел пожар|last=BFM.ru|work=BFM.ru - деловой портал|access-date=2017-12-31|language=ru}} * On 18:45 on August 31, 2015, a fire occurred on the 33rd floor of Federation Tower East/Vostok due to the ignition of construction materials.{{Cite news|url=https://gantbpm.ru/news/pozhar-v-mmdc-moskva-siti/|title=Пожар в ММДЦ Москва-Сити Башня Федерация Восток|work=Консалтинговая компания GANTBPM Управление проектами фирма Москва|access-date=2017-12-31|language=ru-RU}} * On April 13, 2016, a worker fell to his death on the [[Naberezhnaya Tower]], presumably from the hundredth floor.{{Cite news|url=https://lenta.ru/news/2016/04/13/chp/|title=C небоскреба в "Москва-Сити" упал мужчина|access-date=2017-12-31}} * On June 18, 2017, [[roofer]] Sergey Delyashov [[Buildering|climbed]] on [[Eurasia (building)|Eurasia/Steel Peak]] and was later rescued.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ntv.ru/novosti/1822058/|title=На стене небоскреба в "Москва-Сити" заметили неизвестного человека|last=ntv.ru|website=НТВ|language=en|access-date=2017-12-31}} ==See also== Other [[Commercial district|commercial districts]] in Russia: * [[Lakhta Center]] * [[Yekaterinburg City]] Building revision.text:
{{AfricanAmerican|right}}
The '''National Black Chamber of Commerce''' ('''NBCC''') was incorporated as ''The National Black Chamber of Commerce, Inc.'', in 1993. It is a [[nonprofit]], [[nonpartisan]], [[nonsectarian]] [[organization]] dedicated to the economic [[empowerment]] of [[African American]] communities. Additionally, the organization indicates that it represents the views of its members regarding economic and political policy issues; domestically and internationally. It is organized as a [[501(c)]] corporation and has at least 190 chapters within the United States. The NBCC also has international chapters in the [[Bahamas]], [[Brazil]], [[Colombia]], [[Ghana]] and [[Jamaica]].<ref> {{cite web | url=http://www.nationalbcc.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=25&Itemid=9 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928081848/http://www.nationalbcc.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=25&Itemid=9 | dead-url=yes | archive-date=2007-09-28 | title=National Black Chamber of Commerce - About Us, Organizational Profile | accessdate=2007-02-19 }} </ref> As with all [[Chamber of Commerce|Chambers of Commerce]], affiliate branches are committed to carrying out the goals of the main Chamber within their areas.
However, the organization is largely funded by non-African American businesses on behalf of whose interests it often lobbies, such as the [[Fossil fuel industry|fossil fuel]], [[telecommunications]],<ref name="Davies2015">{{cite web|last1=Davies|first1=Ken|title=National Black Chamber of Commerce: Fossil Funders Revealed|url=http://www.climateinvestigations.org/national-black-chamber-of-commerce-fossil-funders-revealed|website=Climate Investigations Center|accessdate=27 March 2017}}</ref><ref name="Kushnick2007">{{cite web|last1=Kushnick|first1=Bruce|title=Verizon, AT&T and the manipulation of public opinion|url=http://www.niemanwatchdog.org/index.cfm?fuseaction=background.view&backgroundid=167|website=Nieman Watchdog|publisher=Nieman Foundation at Harvard University|accessdate=27 March 2017|date=4 April 2007}}</ref><ref name="Dampier2009">{{cite web|last1=Dampier|first1=Philip|title=Special Report — Astroturf Overload – Broadband for America = One Giant Industry Front Group|url=http://stopthecap.com/2009/10/02/special-report-astroturf-overload-broadband-for-america-one-giant-industry-front-group/|accessdate=27 March 2017}}</ref> and [[tobacco industry|tobacco industries]],<ref name="Lorber2011">{{cite news|last1=Lorber|first1=Janie|title=Some Question Black Chamber of Commerce|url=http://www.rollcall.com/news/Black-Chamber-of-Commerce-Questions-205755-1.html|accessdate=27 March 2017|work=[[Roll Call]]|date=18 May 2011}}</ref><ref name="YergerMalone">{{cite journal|last1=Yerger VB, Malone RE|title=African American leadership groups: smoking with the enemy|journal=Tobacco Control|date=December 2002|volume=11|issue=4|pages=336–45|pmid=12432159|url=http://tobaccocontrol.bmj.com/content/11/4/336.long|doi=10.1136/tc.11.4.336|pmc=1747674}}</ref> and has sometimes been accused of being a [[front group]].<ref name="Dampier2009"/><ref name="Davies2015"/><ref name="Alvarado2015">{{cite news|last1=Alvarado|first1=Francisco|title=National Black Chamber of Commerce, Solar Energy Critic, Rakes in Cash From Polluters|url=http://fcir.org/2015/08/13/national-black-chamber-of-commerce-solar-energy-critic-rakes-in-cash-from-polluters/|accessdate=27 March 2017|work=Florida Center for Investigative Reporting|date=13 August 2015}}</ref>
==Origin== The NBCC is a very young national organization when compared to others such as the [[NAACP]] and the [[Congress on Racial Equality]] (CORE). NBCC was founded in 1993 by Harry C. Alford and his wife Kay DeBow.<ref name=fcir20150813/> Alford, who serves as the first President and CEO, is also a Board member of the [[United States Chamber of Commerce]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.uschamber.com/about/board/all.htm |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20030112113315/http://www.uschamber.com/about/board/all.htm |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 2003-01-12 |title = U. S. Chamber of Commerce - Board of Directors |accessdate = 2007-03-13 |df = }}</ref> In an interview reported in ''[[Human Events]]'', Mr. Alford identifies with the [[Booker T. Washington]] approach to African American self empowerment and sees the approach of [[W.E.B. Du Bois]] and the [[NAACP]] (whom he calls ''enemies of Washington'') as primarily political.<ref>{{cite web | last = D'Agostino | first = Joseph A. | title = Conservative Spotlight: National Black Chamber of Commerce | url=http://www.humanevents.com/article.php?id=4723 | date = 2004-08-05 | accessdate = 2007-03-14 }}</ref>
==Mission and strategic goals== The stated mission of the NBCC is to "economically empower and sustain African American communities through entrepreneurship and capitalistic activity within the United States and via interaction with the Black [[Diaspora]]".<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.nationalbcc.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=37&Itemid=48 | title=National Black Chamber of Commerce - Strategic Plan | accessdate=2007-02-19 }}</ref> It claims to be the first major African American organization to focus on economic empowerment.
The NBCC works to fulfill its mission by implementing the following goals:{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} *Increase [[business development]] and [[economic growth]] within the African American community via [[procurement]], access to [[Capital (economics)|capital]] and [[international trade]]. *Secure [[sponsorship]] for the [[funding]] and guidance of NBCC programs. *Educate and train members of the African American community regarding business development and their purpose to benefit society. *Provide [[technical support]] to affiliate chapters.
===Business development=== {{Unreferenced section|date=January 2017}} The NBCC reaches 100,000 Black owned businesses. There are 1 million Black owned businesses in the United States. Black businesses account for over $100 billion in annual sales. African Americans have over $800 billion in expendable income each year according to the US Bureau of Census.
===Funding===
The NBCC "is funded primarily by fossil fuel energy companies, including [[Koch Industries]] and ExxonMobil," according to a 2015 analysis by the [[Florida Center for Investigative Reporting]].<ref name=fcir20150813>{{cite news |agency=[[Florida Center for Investigative Reporting]] |title=National Black Chamber of Commerce, Solar Energy Critic, Rakes in Cash From Polluters |date=August 13, 2015 |first=Francisco |last=Alvarado |url=http://fcir.org/2015/08/13/national-black-chamber-of-commerce-solar-energy-critic-rakes-in-cash-from-polluters/ |accessdate=January 20, 2017}}</ref> [[Exxon Mobil]] includes the NBCC on its 2004 list of contributions and community investments.<ref>{{cite paper |title = Exxon Mobil Corporation 2004 Worldwide Contributions and Community Investments |url = http://www.exxonmobil.com/corporate/files/corporate/giving04_publicpolicy.pdf |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20060212153705/http://www.exxonmobil.com/corporate/files/corporate/giving04_publicpolicy.pdf |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 2006-02-12 |format = [[PDF]] |accessdate = 2007-02-26 |df = }}</ref><ref name=mma20150626>{{cite news |url=http://mediamatters.org/research/2015/06/26/national-black-chamber-of-commerce-joins-oil-in/204153 |accessdate=January 20, 2017 |title=National Black Chamber Of Commerce Joins Oil Industry's Op-Ed Campaign Against EPA Climate Plan; Exxon-Funded Outfit Peddles Debunked Studies To Dispute Clean Power Plan's Benefit For Blacks And Hispanics |date=June 26, 2015 |first1=Andrew |last1=Seifter |first2=Denise |last2=Robbins |publisher=[[Media Matters for America]]}}</ref> From 2002 through 2014 NBCC received $1 million,<ref name=fcir20150813/> and from 2008 through 2015 $800,000, from Exxon Mobil.<ref>{{cite news |title=ExxonMobil Is Still Spending Millions of Dollars on Climate Science Deniers |date=July 16, 2015 |first=Elliott |last=Negin |accessdate=January 20, 2017 |publisher=[[The Huffington Post]] |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/elliott-negin/exxonmobil-is-still-spend_b_7810880.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Exxon Continued Paying Millions To Climate-Change Deniers Under Rex Tillerson |date=January 9, 2017 |first=Alexander C. |last=Kaufman |accessdate=January 20, 2017 |publisher=[[The Huffington Post]] |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/tillerson-exxon-climate-donations_us_5873a3f4e4b043ad97e48f52}}</ref><ref name=wapo20150928>{{cite news |title=In smog battle, industry gets help from unlikely source: black business group |first=Joby |last=Warrick |date=September 28, 2015 |accessdate=January 20, 2017|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/health-science/in-smog-battle-industry-gets-help-from-unlikely-source-black-business-group/2015/09/28/8c1c7e34-63c8-11e5-9757-e49273f05f65_story.html}}</ref> In June 2015 [[Peabody Energy]] contributed $10,000 to the NBCC.<ref name=ucs20160630>{{cite web |url=http://blog.ucsusa.org/gretchen-goldman/peabody-energy-discloses-extensive-payments-to-climate-denial-groups |accessdate=January 20, 2017 |title=Peabody Energy Discloses Extensive Payments to Climate Denial Groups |first=Gretchen |last=Goldman |date=June 30, 2016 |publisher=[[Union of Concerned Scientists]]}}</ref> Other fossil fuel companies that have funded NBCC include the [[Gulf Power Company]] division of the [[Southern Company]]<ref name=fcir20150813/> and [[Chevron Corporation|Chevron]].<ref name=fcir20150813/> The NBCC acknowledges funding from [[fossil fuel]] companies.<ref name=wapo20150928/><ref name=nbccfossil>{{cite web |url=http://www.nationalbcc.org/news/beyond-the-rhetoric/2428-fossil-fuels-and-african-americans-it-s-family |title=Fossil Fuels and African Americans – It’s Family! |publisher=National Black Chamber Of Commerce |last=Alford |first=Harry |accessdate=January 20, 2017}}</ref>
NBCC has also received funding from and lobbied on behalf of the tobacco industry. Tobacco company [[Altria]] was scheduled to sponsor the 2004 Fall Summit meeting in [[Negril]], [[Jamaica]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.theantechamber.net/Jones/Eblast9404.html | title=eBlast September 4, 2004 | accessdate=2007-02-26 }}</ref> It had previously received funding from Altria's predecessor [[Philip Morris Companies Inc]] and from the [[R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company]], and facilitated marketing access to its members.<ref name="YergerMalone"/> In March 2011, Alford appeared before a [[U. S. Food and Drug Administration]] advisory panel to oppose proposed restrictions on [[menthol cigarettes]], which are used disproportionately by African Americans. In doing so, he sided with [[Lorillard]], whose major product was mentholated [[Newport cigarettes]], and which had been an NBCC member since 2008, paying $35,000 in dues annually.<ref name="Lorber2011"/>
NBCC has also received funding from and lobbied on behalf of the telecommunications industry. [[Verizon]] was listed as a funder of NBCC,<ref name="Kushnick2007"/><ref name="Dampier2009"/> which has in turn lobbied the [[Federal Communications Commission]] (FCC) against [[net neutrality]] and other telecommunications industry regulations.<ref name="Kushnick2007"/><ref name="Dampier2009"/> NBCC also voiced support for a proposed merger between [[AT&T]] and [[T-Mobile]].<ref name="Lorber2011"/>
[[Hewlett Packard]] sponsored the 2003 Annual [[Convention (meeting)|convention]] in [[Birmingham, Alabama]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.hp.com/hpinfo/newsroom/press/2003/030731b.html |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20030806183812/http://www.hp.com/hpinfo/newsroom/press/2003/030731b.html |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 2003-08-06 |title = HP News Release |accessdate = 2007-02-26 |df = }}</ref> [[Lord Abbett]] and [[New York Life]] participated with the NBCC in the sponsorship of the ''Building Wealth Tour''.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.newyorklife.com/cda/0,3254,14358,00.html |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20041211165753/http://www.newyorklife.com/cda/0,3254,14358,00.html |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 2004-12-11 |title = New York Life Insurance Company, The National Black Chamber of Commerce and Lord Abbett Kick-Off The Building Wealth Tour for African-American Small Business Owners |accessdate = 2007-02-26 |df = }}</ref> The [[American Chemistry Council]] has also funded NBCC.<ref name=fcir20150813/>
In 2015, Florida Congressman [[Alcee Hastings]] urged NBCC to cut ties with industry groups that spread misinformation on air pollution.<ref name=fcir20150813/><ref>{{cite news |title=Will Florida Voters Be Duped Into Killing Solar Power? |first=Samantha |last=Schuyler |date=November 4, 2016 |magazine=[[The Nation]] |url=https://www.thenation.com/article/will-florida-voters-be-duped-into-killing-solar-power/ |accessdate=January 20, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=Alcee |last=Hastings |authorlink=Alcee Hastings |title=Hastings Urges the National Black Chamber Of Commerce to Cut Ties With Polluters |location=[[Fort Lauderdale, Florida]] |date=August 7, 2015 |accessdate=January 20, 2017 |url=http://alceehastings.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=398461 |publisher=[[Alcee Hastings]]}}</ref>
==Positions==
The NBCC takes positions on federal and state legislation and issues that may affect its goals.
The NBCC "has been a staunch ally of utility and fossil fuel companies for nearly a quarter century," according to the [[Florida Center for Investigative Reporting]].<ref name=fcir20150813/>
* In 1998, Alford testified before the [[United States Congress]] that the [[Kyoto Protocol]] would harm minority-owned small businesses.<ref name=fcir20150813/> * In testimony submitted to the [[United States Senate|Senate]] [[United States Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions|Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions]] regarding Senate Bill S.625, the NBCC stated that it opposes increased the U.S. [[Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA) regulation of tobacco. The reason for its opposition is that the regulation would impose fees affecting small tobacco retailing and distribution businesses in the U.S., many of which are owned by [[Black American]]s.<ref>{{cite web | title = National Black Chamber Opposes New FDA Tobacco Regulations | url=http://www.blackenterprise.com/yb/ybopen.asp?section=ybaa&story_id=103999633&ID=blackenterprise | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928060823/http://www.blackenterprise.com/yb/ybopen.asp?section=ybaa&story_id=103999633&ID=blackenterprise | dead-url=yes | archive-date=2007-09-28 | date = 2007-03-07 | accessdate = 2007-03-19 }}</ref> *In public comments regarding the [[Microsoft antitrust case]], the NBCC along with the Telecommunications Research and Action Center and the National [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] Chamber of Commerce indicated that the case settlement was inadequate in terms of consumer protection and that additional remedies were required.<ref>{{cite web | title = Microsoft Settlement Comments Submitted by the Telecommunications Research & Action Center, National Black Chamber of Commerce, National Native American Chamber of Commerce | url=http://www.usdoj.gov/atr/cases/ms_tuncom/major/mtc-00028893.htm | date = 2002-01-28 | accessdate = 2007-04-09 }}</ref> *The NBCC denies the [[Scientific opinion on climate change|scientific consensus on climate change]], stating on their website that "...there is no sound science to support the claims of Global Warming."<ref name=nbccenv/><ref name=ucsnbccreport/> In 2009, NBCC opposed the [[American Clean Energy and Security Act]], a proposed [[emissions trading]] plan.<ref name=nbccenv>{{cite web |url=http://www.nationalbcc.org/news/beyond-the-rhetoric/1623-environmental-racism-global-warming-and-climate-change |title=Environmental Racism, Global Warming and Climate Change |publisher=National Black Chamber of Commerce |first=Harry |last=Alford |accessdate=January 20, 2017}}</ref> *The NBCC supports the [[Keystone XL Pipeline]].<ref name=wapo20150928/><ref name=nbccfossil/><ref>{{cite web |title= Black Business Leader Calls on Obama Administration to Approve Keystone XL |date=October 7, 2011 |publisher=National Black Chamber of Commerce |accessdate=January 20, 2017 |url=http://www.nationalbcc.org/96-uncategorised/1400-black-business-leader-calls-on-obama-administration-to-approve-keystone-xl}}</ref> *In 2015 the NBCC opposed the [[Environmental Protection Agency]]'s [[Clean Power Plan]].<ref name=mma20150626/><ref name=ucs20160630/> In June 2015 NBCC released a report entitled ''Potential Impact of Proposed EPA Regulations on Low Income Groups and Minorities'';<ref name=ucs20160630/> the [[Union of Concerned Scientists]] said the report "relies on misleading claims cut-and-pasted from several previously debunked reports."<ref name=ucsnbccreport>{{cite web |url=http://www.ucsusa.org/global-warming/fight-misinformation/national-black-chamber-commerce-study-clean-power-plan |title=National Black Chamber of Commerce Report on Clean Power Plan |publisher=[[Union of Concerned Scientists]] |date=August 19, 2015 |accessdate=January 20, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=New Flawed Study of the Clean Power Plan: How the MISI Study Gets It So Wrong |first=John |last=Rogers |date=June 12, 2015 |accessdate=January 20, 2017 |publisher=[[Union of Concerned Scientists]] |url=http://blog.ucsusa.org/john-rogers/new-flawed-study-of-the-clean-power-plan-how-the-misi-study-gets-it-so-wrong-759}}</ref> Seven newspapers published [[op-ed]]s from the NBCC saying that the Plan will impose "economic hardship" on blacks and Hispanics; none of the newspapers disclosed NBCC's funding from the Exxon Mobil Foundation.<ref name=mma20150626/>
==Organization== {{Unreferenced section|date=January 2017}} *[[Board of Directors]] - The Board consists of no more than 18 Directors at any given time. It develops, implements and supervises the policies of the Chamber and elects all officers. *[[Corporate title#Corporate titles|Officers]] - The Chamber officers are elected from among the Board, and consist of the Chairman of the Board, President/CEO, Secretary, Treasurer, one or more Vice Presidents and other officers as determined by the Board. *Members - Local member and student member chapters; and individuals, businesses and organizations that prefer direct membership to the National Chamber.
==References== * {{cite web | url=http://www.nationalbcc.org | title=National Black Chamber of Commerce | accessdate=2007-02-19 }}
===Citations=== <references/>
[[Category:Chambers of commerce]] [[Category:African-American professional organizations]]

revision.text:
'''National Core Indicators''' (NCI) is a collaborative effort between the [[National Association of State Directors of Developmental Disabilities Services]]<ref>{{Cite web|title = Welcome - NASDDDS|url = http://www.nasddds.org/|website = www.nasddds.org|accessdate = 2015-11-20}}</ref> (NASDDDS) and the [[Human Services Research Institute]]<ref>{{Cite web|title = Welcome {{!}} Human Services Research Institute (HSRI)|url = http://www.hsri.org/|website = www.hsri.org|accessdate = 2015-11-20}}</ref> (HSRI) in the [[United States]]. The purpose of the program, which began in 1997,<ref>{{Cite journal|title = National Core Indicators: Ten Years of Collaborative Performance Measurement. Intellectual and Developmental Disabilities|url = http://www.aaiddjournals.org/doi/abs/10.1352/0047-6765%25282007%252945%255B354%253ANCITYO%255D2.0.CO%253B2?journalCode=mere|doi = 10.1352/0047-6765(2007)45[354:ncityo]2.0.co;2 | volume=45|journal=Intellectual and Developmental Disabilities|pages=354–358}}</ref> is to support NASDDDS member agencies (state [[Developmental disability|developmental disabilities]] agencies) to gather a standard set of [[Performance measurement|performance]] and outcome measures that can be used to track their own performance over time, to compare results across states, and to establish national [[Benchmarking|benchmarks]].
The primary aim of NCI is to collect and maintain valid and reliable data about the performance of public developmental disabilities [[Service system|service systems]]. NCI states and project partners use NCI data not only to improve practice at the state level but also to add knowledge to the field, to influence state and national policy, and to inform strategic planning initiatives for NASDDDS.
Through participation in the program, NCI states make a commitment to share information with [[Stakeholder theory|stakeholders]] so that data can be used for policy change and [[Quality management|quality improvement]]. To that end, the National Core Indicators website<ref>{{Cite web|title = Welcome {{!}} National Core Indicators|url = http://www.nationalcoreindicators.org|website = www.nationalcoreindicators.org|accessdate = 2015-11-20}}</ref> provides public access to NCI data and current information about how the results are being used at the state and national levels to support policy, [[research]], and [[advocacy]] efforts.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xJi89H2oyAY|title = YouTube Video: Why is the NCI important?|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = Allen|first = Bill}}</ref>
== The National Core Indicators framework == The NCI framework comprises an '''Adult Consumer Survey''', three family [[Survey methodology|surveys]] ('''The''' '''Adult Family Survey''', '''The''' '''Family/Guardian Survey''' and '''The''' '''Children/Family Survey''') and '''The''' '''Staff Stability Survey'''.
=== The Adult Consumer Survey === '''The Adult Consumer Survey''' is completed with a minimum of 400 individuals (per participating state) who are 18 years of age or older and receiving at least one paid service in addition to [[Case management (US health system)|case management]]. There are over 100 key outcome indicators in the survey that are designed to gather valid and reliable data across five broad domains: individual outcomes; family outcomes; health, welfare and rights; staff stability; and system performance. The survey has three components; background data, and two interview sections. The background data is most frequently completed by service coordinators prior to the face-to-face survey and includes information about general demographics; where people live, work, health information, etc. The interview part of the survey must be conducted face to face with the individual receiving services. The first section can only be answered by the individual. The second section of the survey may be completed by a proxy if the interviewer determines the individual cannot answer for him or herself or if the individual does not want to respond<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Responsiveness to Self-Report Interview Questions by Adults With Intellectual and Developmental Disability|url = http://www.aaiddjournals.org/doi/abs/10.1352/1934-9556-53.3.163|journal = Intellectual and Developmental Disabilities|date = 2015-06-01|issn = 1934-9491|pages = 163–181|volume = 53|issue = 3|doi = 10.1352/1934-9556-53.3.163|first = Roger J.|last = Stancliffe|first2 = Renáta|last2 = Tichá|first3 = Sheryl A.|last3 = Larson|first4 = Amy S.|last4 = Hewitt|first5 = Derek|last5 = Nord}}</ref> the NCI team provides training for interviewers who administer the survey. Completed surveys are entered using a secure online data entry system designed by HSRI.
=== The National Core Indicator Family Surveys ===
==== The Adult Family Survey ==== The Adult Family Survey is completed by a minimum of 400 respondents (per participating state) who have an adult family member with I/DD living in the family home. This survey is mailed out to families to be completed. Returned survey information is entered into a secure on-line data entry system designed and managed by HSRI. States report response rates of between 35%- 40%.
==== The Family/Guardian Survey ==== The Family/Guardian Survey is completed with a minimum of 400 respondents (per participating state) who have an adult family member with I/DD living outside the family home. This survey is mailed out to families to be completed. Returned survey information is entered into a secure on-line data entry system designed and managed by HSRI. States report response rates of between 35%- 40%.
==== The Children/Family Survey ==== The Children/Family Survey is completed with a minimum of 400 respondents (per participating state) who have a child family member with I/DD living in the family home. This survey is mailed out to families to be completed. Returned survey information is entered into a secure on-line data entry system designed and managed by HSRI. States report response rates of between 35%- 40%.
==== The Staff Stability Survey ==== The Staff Stability Survey is completed by all provider agencies (within participating states) supporting adults with I/DD in residential, employment, day services and other in-home or community inclusion programs. The survey is intended to capture information about the direct support professional (DSP) workforce such as [[Turnover (employment)|turnover]], vacancy rates, wages, types of services provided, and benefits offered. Each state provides HSRI with agency emails and the provider agencies respond directly into HSRI's on-line data entry system.
== Reports and publications == Data from NCI surveys are aggregated and analyzed in reports produced yearly.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Reports {{!}} National Core Indicators|url = http://www.nationalcoreindicators.org/resources/reports/|website = www.nationalcoreindicators.org|accessdate = 2015-11-21}}</ref> These data are used to support state efforts to strengthen long term care [[policy]],<ref>{{Cite web|title = National Data Measurement Project: National Core Indicators|url = http://www.acl.gov/Programs/AIDD/Program_Resource_Search/Resources/DataMeasurement_NationalCore.aspx|website = www.acl.gov|accessdate = 2015-11-20}}</ref> inform the conduct of quality assurance activities, and compare performance with national norms. Additionally, NCI data have been used as the basis of data briefs<ref>{{Cite web|title = Data Briefs {{!}} National Core Indicators|url = http://www.nationalcoreindicators.org/resources/data-briefs/|website = www.nationalcoreindicators.org|accessdate = 2015-11-20}}</ref> on specific areas of interest such as employment, dual diagnosis, self-directed services, and autism spectrum disorders, and the results of analyses of the multi-state dataset have been published in academic research journals<ref>{{Cite web|title = Publications {{!}} National Core Indicators|url = http://www.nationalcoreindicators.org/resources/publications/|website = www.nationalcoreindicators.org|accessdate = 2015-11-20}}</ref> and presented at conferences. NCI has also been cited as a "Resource on [[Autism]]" by [[NBC News]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Resources on Autism|url = http://www.nbcnews.com/dateline/resources-autism-n340291|website = NBC News|accessdate = 2015-11-21}}</ref> NCI indicators contribute to the calculation of state rankings in [[United Cerebral Palsy]]'s report ''The Case for Inclusion''.<ref>{{Cite web|title = The Case for Inclusion 2015|url = http://cfi.ucp.org/|website = cfi.ucp.org|accessdate = 2015-11-23}}</ref>
Data from the National Core Indicators surveys also provide a rich source of data on demographics, personal characteristics, work status, and services received. These data, together with NCI data on outcomes, have been used in many [[Peer review|peer-reviewed]] research articles and presentations.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Health disparities among adults with developmental disabilities, adults with other disabilities, and adults not reporting disability in North Carolina.|journal = Public Health Reports|date = 2004-01-01|issn = 0033-3549|pmc = 1497651|pmid = 15219799|pages = 418–426|volume = 119|issue = 4|doi = 10.1016/j.phr.2004.05.006|first = Susan M.|last = Havercamp|first2 = Donna|last2 = Scandlin|first3 = Marcia|last3 = Roth}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Mental Health for People With Intellectual Disability: The Impact of Stress and Social Support|url = http://www.aaiddjournals.org/doi/abs/10.1352/1944-7558-119.6.552|journal = American Journal on Intellectual and Developmental Disabilities|date = 2014-10-29|issn = 1944-7515|pages = 552–564|volume = 119|issue = 6|doi = 10.1352/1944-7558-119.6.552|first = Haleigh M.|last = Scott|first2 = Susan M.|last2 = Havercamp}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Impact of Adulthood Stage and Social-Environmental Context on Body Mass Index and Physical Activity of Individuals With Intellectual Disability|url = http://www.aaiddjournals.org/doi/abs/10.1352/1934-9556-53.2.100|journal = Intellectual and Developmental Disabilities|date = 2015-04-01|issn = 1934-9491|pages = 100–113|volume = 53|issue = 2|doi = 10.1352/1934-9556-53.2.100|first = Kelly|last = Hsieh|first2 = Tamar|last2 = Heller|first3 = Julie|last3 = Bershadsky|first4 = Sarah|last4 = Taub}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Empirically Derived Model of Social Outcomes and Predictors for Adults With ASD|url = http://www.aaiddjournals.org/doi/abs/10.1352/1934-9556-52.4.282|journal = Intellectual and Developmental Disabilities|date = 2014-07-25|issn = 1934-9491|pages = 282–295|volume = 52|issue = 4|doi = 10.1352/1934-9556-52.4.282|first = Margaret H.|last = Mehling|first2 = Marc J.|last2 = Tassé}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Place of Residence and Preventive Health Care for Intellectual and Developmental Disabilities Services Recipients in 20 States|journal = Public Health Reports|date = 2012-01-01|issn = 0033-3549|pmc = 3407847|pmid = 22942465|pages = 475–485|volume = 127|issue = 5|first = Julie|last = Bershadsky|first2 = Sarah|last2 = Taub|first3 = Joshua|last3 = Engler|first4 = Charles R.|last4 = Moseley|first5 = K. Charlie|last5 = Lakin|first6 = Roger J.|last6 = Stancliffe|first7 = Sheryl|last7 = Larson|first8 = Renata|last8 = Ticha|first9 = Caitlin|last9 = Bailey}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Race/Ethnicity and the Use of Preventive Health Care Among A... : Medical Care|url = http://journals.lww.com/lww-medicalcare/Abstract/2014/10001/Race_Ethnicity_and_the_Use_of_Preventive_Health.7.aspx|website = LWW|accessdate = 2015-11-21}}</ref> NCI data is available to researchers through a data request process.
== References == <!--- See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Footnotes on how to create references using<ref></ref> tags, these references will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}
== External links == * http://www.nationalcoreindicators.org/about/ * Measuring Developmental Disabilities Services' Success: http://www.governing.com/topics/health-human-services/col-measuring-developmental-disabilities-services-success.html

'''Open Options Corporation''' is a privately owned business strategy consulting company that specializes in applied [[game theory]] and [[business war games]] where there are multiple stakeholders who can all influence the final outcome of a particular situation.
Open Options’ original software development was funded by the [[CIA]] through a company called Waterloo Engineering Software. The software was designed to help the American government better anticipate the collapse of the Soviet Union into many different breakaway republics.<ref name= "Globe and Mail"> https://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20070125.rmgame0125/BNStory/specialROBmagazine/home </ref> The software was based on academic research by Dr. Niall Fraser from the [[University of Waterloo]]. Dr. Fraser has written several books on game theory including Mathematical Modeling of Resolutions of Conflict<ref name= "Mathematical Modeling of Resolutions"> Okada, N, K.W. Hipel, N.M. Fraser and M. Fukushima (1988). Mathematical Modeling of Resolutions of Conflict, Kyoto Japan: Gendai Sugakusha (in Japanese).</ref> and Conflict Analysis: Models and Resolutions.<ref name= "Conflict Analysis"> Fraser, N.M. and K.W. Hipel (1984). Conflict Analysis: Models and Resolutions. New York: North-Holland. </ref>
Open Options uses a type of game theory called Ordinal Non-cooperative Game Theory which is a less well-known sub-section of game theory.<ref name = "Globe and Mail" /> However, this approach and proprietary software enables Open Options to analyze millions of possible outcomes.<ref name = "Globe and Mail" /><ref name= "Economist">http://www.economist.com/business/displaystory.cfm?story_id=9257879 </ref><ref name= "Risk Management Magazine"> http://www.rmmag.com/MGTemplate.cfm?Section=MagArchive&NavMenuID=304&template=/Magazine/DisplayMagazines.cfm&Archive=1&IssueID=212&AID=2316&Volume=51&ShowArticle=1</ref><ref name= "CFO magazine"> http://www.cfo.com/article.cfm/11700044?f=search </ref>
==References== {{Reflist}} [https://pdx.academia.edu/nathanFlow business ideas]
==External links== *[http://openoptions.com Company website]
[[Category:Game theory]] [[Category:Business planning]] [[Category:Consulting firms]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2017}} The '''open music model''' is an economic and technological framework for the [[recording industry]] based on research conducted at the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]]. It predicts that the playback of prerecorded music will be regarded as a service rather than as individually sold products, and that the only system for the [[digital distribution]] of music that will be viable against piracy is a subscription-based system supporting [[file sharing]] and free of [[digital rights management]]. The research also indicated that [[United States dollar|US$]]9 per month for unlimited use would be the [[market clearing]] price at that time, but recommended $5 per month as the long-term optimal price.<ref name=MIT>{{cite web|url=http://dspace.mit.edu/handle/1721.1/8438|title=Advanced Peer-Based Technology Business Models|author=[[Shuman Ghosemajumder]]|publisher=[[MIT Sloan School of Management]]|date=May 10, 2002}}</ref>
Since its creation in 2002, a number of its principles have been adopted throughout the recording industry,<ref name=irunway>{{cite web|url=http://www.i-runway.com/blog/on-demand-music-streaming-to-battle-piracy/|title=On-Demand Music Streaming to battle Piracy|author=Gautham Somraj Koorma|publisher=[[iRunway]]|date=November 27, 2015}}</ref> and it has been cited as the basis for the business model of many [[Comparison of on-demand streaming music services|music subscription services]].<ref name=lespresso>{{cite web|url=http://espresso.repubblica.it/affari/2014/07/01/news/spotify-il-business-folle-sbarca-a-wall-street-1.171553|title=Spotify, il business folle sbarca a Wall Street|author=Marco Consoli|publisher=[[L'Espresso]]|date=July 3, 2014}}</ref><ref name=gazeta>{{cite web|url=http://technologie.gazeta.pl/internet/1,104665,18056619,Dla_uzytkownikow_streaming_muzyki_jest_spelnieniem.html|title=Dla użytkowników streaming muzyki jest spełnieniem marzeń, a dla wytwórni – źródłem obaw|author=Karol Kopańko|publisher=[[Gazeta.pl]]|date=June 5, 2015}}</ref>
== Overview == The model asserts that there are five [[necessary and sufficient|necessary]] requirements for a viable commercial music digital distribution network: {| class="wikitable" ! # !! style="width: 20%;" | Requirement !! Description |- | 1 || Open file sharing || users must be free to [[file sharing|share files]] with each other |- | 2 || Open file formats || content must be distributed in open formats with no [[digital rights management|DRM]] restrictions |- | 3 || Open membership || [[copyright]] holders must be able to freely register to receive payment |- | 4 || Open payment || payment should be accepted via multiple means, not a closed system |- | 5 || Open competition || multiple such systems must exist which can interoperate, not a designed monopoly |}The model was proposed by [[Shuman Ghosemajumder]] in his 2002 research paper ''Advanced Peer-Based Technology Business Models''<ref name="MIT"/> at the [[MIT Sloan School of Management]]. The following year, it was publicly referred to as the Open Music Model.<ref name="opensource">{{cite web|url=http://opensource.com/life/11/11/drm-graveyard-brief-history-digital-rights-management-music|title=The DRM graveyard: A brief history of digital rights management in music|author=Ruth Suehle|publisher=[[Red Hat]] Magazine|date=November 3, 2011}}</ref>
The model suggests changing the way consumers interact with the digital property market: rather than being seen as a good to be purchased from online vendor, music would be treated as a service being provided by the industry, with firms based on the model serving as intermediaries between the music industry and its consumers. The model proposed giving consumers unlimited access to music for the price of [[United States dollar|US$]]5 per month<ref name=MIT /> (as of 2002), based on research showing that this could be a long-term optimal price, expected to bring in a total revenue of over [[United States dollar|US$]]3 billion per year.<ref name=MIT />
The research demonstrated the demand for third-party file sharing programs. Insofar as the interest for a particular piece of digital property is high, and the risk of acquiring the good via illegitimate means is low, people will naturally flock towards third-party services such as [[Napster]] and Morpheus (more recently, [[BitTorrent (protocol)|Bittorrent]] and [[The Pirate Bay]]).<ref name=MIT />
The research showed that consumers would use file sharing services not primarily due to cost but because of convenience, indicating that services which provided access to the most music would be the most successful.<ref name=MIT />
== Industry adoption == The model predicted the failure of [[digital distribution|online music distribution]] systems based on [[digital rights management]].<ref name=opensource /><ref name=CollectiveCopyright>{{cite web|url=http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=2602197|title=Collective Copyright|author1=Emanuele Lunadei |author2=Christian Valdiva Torres |author3=Erik Cambria |publisher=[[International World Wide Web Conference]] 2014|date=May 18, 2014}}</ref>
Criticisms of the model included that it would not eliminate the issue of piracy.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/120018441/Music-Distribution-Technology-and-the-Value-of-Art-in-Society|title=Music Distribution: Technology and the Value of Art in Society|author=Sungwon Peter Choe|publisher=[[KAIST]]|year=2006}}</ref> Others countered that it was in fact the most viable solution to piracy,<ref> {{cite web|url=http://www.iplawintheus.com/open-music-model/|title=Open music model|author=Andrew Traub|publisher=US Intellectual Property Law|date=November 25, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110101061826/http://www.iplawintheus.com/open-music-model/|archivedate=January 1, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref> since piracy was "inevitable".<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.cse.tkk.fi/Datacommunications/Doctoral_dissertations/Lic-Yrjo_Raivio.pdf | title=Mobile Services and the Internet: A Study of Emerging Business Models|author=Yrjö Raivio|publisher=[[Helsinki University of Technology]]|date=December 4, 2009}}</ref> Supporters argued that it offered a superior alternative to the current [[Trade group efforts against file sharing|law-enforcement based methods]] used by the recording industry.<ref> {{cite web|url=http://mujlt.law.muni.cz/storage/1234798737_sb_06_myska.pdf|title=Flat Fee Music|author=Matěj Myška|publisher=[[Masaryk University Journal of Law and Technology]]|date=December 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718175953/http://mujlt.law.muni.cz/storage/1234798737_sb_06_myska.pdf|archivedate=July 18, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref> One startup in Germany, Playment, announced plans to adapt the entire model to a commercial setting as the basis for its business model.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.playment.net/solution/index.html|title=Playment – Our Solution|author=Playment|publisher=playment.com}}</ref>
Several aspects of the model have been adopted by the recording industry and its partners over time:
{{quote box |width=40% |quote=Why would the big four music companies agree to let Apple and others distribute their music without using DRM systems to protect it? The simplest answer is because DRMs haven't worked, and may never work, to halt music piracy. |source=– [[Steve Jobs]], ''Thoughts on Music''<ref name=stevejobs /> open letter, 2007 }}
* The abolition of digital rights management represented a major shift for the industry. In 2007, [[Steve Jobs]], CEO of [[Apple Inc.|Apple]], published a letter<ref name=stevejobs>{{cite web|url=https://www.apple.com/kr/hotnews/thoughtsonmusic/|title=Thoughts on Music|author=[[Steve Jobs]]|publisher=[[Apple Inc.]]|date=February 6, 2007}}</ref> calling for an end to DRM in music. A few months later, [[Amazon.com]] launched a store single individual DRM-free mp3's.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.readwriteweb.com/archives/amazon_mp3.php|title=Amazon MP3 Launches DRM-Free Music Store|author=Marshall Kirkpatrick|publisher=[[ReadWriteWeb]]|date=September 25, 2007}}</ref> One year later, iTunes Store abolished DRM on most of its individual tracks.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.macworld.com/article/137946/2009/01/itunestore.html|title=iTunes Store goes DRM-free|author=Peter Cohen|publisher=[[MacWorld]]|date=January 6, 2009}}</ref> * Open payment was relatively straightforward to implement, and the [[iTunes Store]] offered gift cards, which could be purchased with cash, from its launch in 2003. * In 2010, [[Rhapsody (online music service)|Rhapsody]] announced a download ability<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.fastcompany.com/1627779/rhapsody-streaming-music-mp3-playlists-iphone-itunes-apple-ipad-entertainment|title=Rhapsody First Subscription Service in U.S. to Offer Offline Music on iPhone|author=Kit Eaton|publisher=[[FastCompany]]|date=April 26, 2010}}</ref> for their subscribers using [[iPhones]]. * In 2011, Apple launched its [[iTunes Match]] service with a subscription model, supporting file-sharing between a user's own devices.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://erikras.com/2011/11/16/cloud-music-and-itunes-match/|title=Cloud Music and iTunes Match|author=Erik Rasmussen|date=November 16, 2011}}</ref> However, the subscription price did not include the cost of acquiring content, which would still have to be purchased on a per track basis from the iTunes Store. * Pricing close to the model's suggested $5 per month price, or its $9 per month market clearing price, has been adopted by many platforms: ** In 2005, [[Yahoo! Music]] was launched at $5 per month with [[digital rights management]]. ** In 2011, [[Spotify]] introduced a $5 per month premium subscription in the United States with [[digital rights management]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/epicenter/2011/07/spotify-launches-in-the-u-s-at-last/|title=Spotify Launches in the U.S at Last|author=Charlie Sorrel|publisher=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]|date=July 14, 2011}}</ref> ** In 2011, [[Microsoft]] [[Zune]] offered a subscription service for music downloads with [[digital rights management]] known as a [[Zune Pass]], at $10 a month. ** in 2012, [[Google Play Music]] launched unlimited music streaming for a subscription price of $9.99 per month.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/2015/06/24/first-look---google-play-music-has-1000s-of-free-music-playlists/29220015/|title=First Look – Google Play Music has 1000s of free music playlists|author=Jefferson Graham|publisher=[[USA Today]]|date=June 24, 2015}}</ref> Users can upload their own MP3s to the service and download them, but cannot download songs they have not uploaded themselves. ** In 2014, [[Amazon.com|Amazon]] added DRM music streaming to their Amazon Prime service.<ref>http://www.windowsobserver.com/2014/06/12/the-gotchas-of-the-amazon-prime-music-service/</ref> ** In 2015, Apple announced [[Apple Music]], which would offer unlimited streaming of songs encrypted with [[FairPlay]] DRM for a subscription price of $9.99 per month, and compensate artists on the basis of song popularity. Apple reportedly wanted to enter the market with a lower price but was pressured by record labels to adopt a higher subscription fee.<ref name="Verge">{{cite web |url=https://www.theverge.com/2015/6/8/8729481/apple-music-streaming-service-wwdc-15 |accessdate=June 8, 2015 |title=Apple announces its streaming music service, Apple Music |last1=Popper |first1=Ben |last2=Singleton |first2=Micah |date=June 8, 2015 |work=[[The Verge]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Z8hZFUn5?url=http://www.theverge.com/2015/6/8/8729481/apple-music-streaming-service-wwdc-15 |archivedate=June 8, 2015 |deadurl=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref>

'''PowerLab''' (before 1998 was referred to as MacLab) is a [[data acquisition]] system developed by [[ADInstruments]] comprising hardware and software and designed for use in life science research<ref>[https://scholar.google.com.au/scholar?hl=en&q=adinstruments&btnG=Search&as_sdt=0%2C5&as_ylo=&as_vis=0 Papers on Google Scholar] Reference to ADInstruments & PowerLab</ref> and teaching applications. It is commonly used in physiology, pharmacology, biomedical engineering, sports/exercise studies and psychophysiology laboratories to record and analyse physiological signals from human or animal subjects or from isolated organs. The system consists of an input device connected to a [[Microsoft Windows]] or [[Mac OS]] computer using a [[USB]] cable and LabChart software which is supplied with the PowerLab and provides the recording, display and analysis functions. The use of PowerLab and supplementary [[ADInstruments]] products have been demonstrated on the Journal of Visualised Experiments.<ref>[http://www.jove.com/search.php?q=adinstruments JOVE: Journal of Visualised Experiments] using PowerLab</ref>
The original '''MacLab''' unit was developed in the late 1980s to run with only [[Macintosh]] computers to perform computer-based [[data acquisition]] and analysis. The MacLab product range was renamed "PowerLab" in 1997 to reflect the cross-platform nature of the system.
The PowerLab system is essentially a peripheral device designed to perform various functions needed for [[data acquisition]], [[signal conditioning]] and pre-processing.<ref name="powerlab" >{{cite web | title = Pushing Hardware to the Limits. | page = | work = | publisher = Apple Inc Online | year = 2003 | url = https://www.apple.com/au/pr/casestudies/2003/09/adinstruments/scientific5.html| accessdate = 2008-12-22 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> Versatile display options and analysis functions are complemented by the ability to export data to other software (such as Microsoft Excel).
==How is data acquired?<sup><ref name="dataacquisition" >{{cite web | title = Recent Developments in Data Recording Systems for Physiology | page = | work = | publisher = Pak J Physiology | year = 2006 | url = http://pps.org.pk/PJP/2-1/NaumanAziz.pdf| accessdate = 2008-12-17}}</ref></sup>==
* External signals detected are converted into analog electrical signal * Signals are amplified to amplify signals and filtered to remove unwanted frequencies or noise * Analog signal is multiplexed to an [[analog to digital converter]] * The digitized signal is transmitted to the computer using USB connection * Software receives, displays, analyses and records data in real time
==PowerLab Models==
===Current=== * /35 Series for research: Released in 2011. Includes PowerLab 4/35, PowerLab 8/35 and PowerLab 16/35. * /30 Series for research: Released in 2004. Includes PowerLab 4/30, PowerLab 8/30 and PowerLab 16/30. * /26 Series for teaching: Released in 2007. Includes PowerLab 2/26, PowerLab 4/26, PowerLab26T * /T Series for teaching: Released in 2007. Includes PowerLab 15T
===Previous===
* Original MacLab: First released November 1988. Includes MacLab/4 and MacLab/8. * E series: First released October 1992. Includes MacLab /2e, MacLab /4e, MacLab /8e, MacLab /200, PowerLab /200, MacLab /400, PowerLab /400, PowerLab /410, PowerLab /415, and PowerLab /800 * S series: First released August 1994. For SCSI connection only and includes MacLab /4S, PowerLab /4S, PowerLab /8S and PowerLab /16S. * SP series: First released May 1999. For SCSI and USB connections and includes PowerLab /4SP, PowerLab /8SP, PowerLab /16SP, and PowerLab 4ST. * /20 series: First released July 2000. USB connections only and includes PowerLab 2/20, PowerLab 4/20, and PowerLab 4/20T. * /T series: First released September 2002. PowerLab 10T for teaching. * /25 series: First released September 2003. Requires high speed USB 2.0 connections and includes PowerLab 2/25, PowerLab 4/25, and PowerLab 4/25T.
==Software for PowerLab==
===LabChart===
Formerly known as Chart. The software functions like a traditional multi-channel [[chart recorder]], [[X–Y plotter|XY plotter]], [[polygraph]] and digital [[voltmeter]]. It is compatible with both Windows and Macintosh operating systems. The software has hardware settings control, performs analysis in real-time and offline without the loss of raw data, procedure automation via editable macros, and multiple block samplings for the recording and settings of different signals within one file.<ref name="macresearch">{{cite web|title=Showcase: LabChart 6 for Turn-Key Data Acquisition. |page= |work= |publisher=MacResearch |date= |url=http://www.macresearch.org/showcase-labchart-6-turn-key-data-acquisition |accessdate=2008-12-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081212015955/http://www.macresearch.org/showcase-labchart-6-turn-key-data-acquisition |archivedate=2008-12-12 |df= }}</ref> Large specialised add-ons called Modules provide data acquisition and analysis features for specific applications such as ECG, blood pressure, cardiac output, HRV etc. Smaller software plugins provide additional and specialized functionality to LabChart. Extensions perform functions such as file translations into other formats (including PVAN and [[IGOR Pro|Igor Pro]]) and specialist analysis functions (for specific research areas such as spirometry and ventricular pressure). The last version of LabChart6 (version 6.1.3) was released on January 2009.
In April 2009, LabChart 7 was released and incorporates the features of a multi-channel digital oscilloscope that allows recording and averaging of up to sixteen signals in real time. Latest version of LabChart7 is version 7.0.
LabChart 8 is also now available.
===LabTutor===
Software provides a range of hands-on laboratory background for students that includes experimental background & protocols, data acquisition & analysis, and report generation within one interface.<ref name="avreview">{{cite journal |author= Vazquez, J |title= AV & Software Reviews |journal= The American Biology Teacher|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_6958/is_3_70/ai_n28524400/pg_1?tag=artBody;col1 |volume=70 |issue=3 |pages=173–174 |year=2008 |doi= 10.1662/0002-7685}}</ref><ref name="inquirybase">{{cite journal |author1=Casotti G. |author2=Rieser-Danner L. |author3=Knabb M.T. |title= Successful implementation of inquiry-based physiology laboratories in undergraduate major and nonmajor courses |journal= Advances in Physiology Education|url=http://advan.physiology.org/cgi/content/full/32/4/286 |volume=32 |pages=286–296 |year=2008 |doi= 10.1152/ADVAN.00100.2007|pmid= 19047505 |issue= 4}}</ref> The software and accompanying PowerLab hardware is configured for immediate use with step by step instructions designed to maximize student productivity by applying independent learning techniques to a suite of human and animal physiological experiments.<ref name="avreview" /> Recently, LabAuthor software was released to provide educators the ability to design or edit existing LabTutor experiments and tailor the experiments to suit their practical classes without the need of programming or html skills.
===Scope===
Records and analyzes high frequency signals that are time-locked to a stimulus. The display allows computer screen to act as an [[oscilloscope]] and [[Xy plotter|XY plotter]]
===Limitations===
The PowerLab messaging protocol is not publicly available and there is no public API for traditional programming languages such as C.

{{Infobox video game |title= Rock Manager |image= Rock Manager coverart.png |caption= |developer= [[PAN Vision]] |publisher= [[DreamCatcher Interactive]] |designer= |series= |engine= |released={{vgrelease|NA|June 30, 2002}} |genre= [[Business simulation game]] |modes= [[Single player]] |platforms=[[Microsoft Windows|Windows]] }}
'''''Rock Manager''''' is a [[business simulation game]] for [[Microsoft Windows]].
==Gameplay== Rock Manager puts the player in control of a [[rock band]] with the task of making them into rockstars.
Play starts with putting a band together. The player chooses from a list of musicians with all tastes and styles. Record a demo in a studio, adding effects to the song to make is fit the band's image. With a demo in hand, it's up to the player to bag a record deal, arrange gigs, promote the record and go on the road. But it is important to keep an eye on the musicians and keep them happy or the band might self-destruct.
Options are selected using an icon system, but recording and practicing takes place in real time.
There are five styles of music you can use: [[Rock music|Rock]], [[Pop music|Pop]], [[Dance]], [[Punk rock|Punk]] and [[heavy metal music|Heavy metal]].
==External links== *{{moby game|id=/rock-manager|name=''Rock Manager''}} *[http://www.gamefaqs.com/computer/doswin/data/561878.html ''Rock Manager''] at [[GameFAQs]]

{{Multiple issues| {{notability|Biographies|date=September 2011}} {{BLP primary sources|date=September 2011}} }}
'''Rudy Duthil''' (born October 16, 1982) is an American advertising executive of Dominican and Cuban descent best known for promoting the use of [[graffiti]] murals for advertising purposes across the United States. Duthil founded (in 2008) and served as director of Zoom Forward, a multicultural marketing division at Zoom Media & Marketing, after serving as their West Coast director of [[Engagement marketing|Experiential Marketing]] & [[Business Development]].<ref>{{cite web|last=McGreen|first=Reilly|title=Rudy Duthil '04 Setting the Bar|url=http://www.uri.edu/quadangles/issue/july-2008/rudy-duthil-04/|publisher=Quadangles|accessdate=July 2008}}</ref> In 2007, Duthil's was recognized by the ADCOLOR Industry Coalition's “ADCOLOR Awards” Rising Star Award.<ref>{{cite web|title=ADCOLOR 2007 Awards to be presented at ANA Multicultural Conference|url=http://targetmarketnews.com/storyid10090702.htm|publisher=Target Market News|accessdate=October 8, 2007}}</ref> He has also been recognized by the Creative Media Awards on three occasions: Best Multicultural Creative Campaigns for [[Nicorette]], [[Greyhound Lines]], and [[Ford]] in 2007, 2008 and 2009.<ref>{{cite web|title=Creative Media Awards|url=http://www.mediapost.com/events/?/showID/CreativeMediaAwards.09.NYC/type/Content/itemID/785/CreativeMediaAwards-2008%20Winners.html|publisher=Media Magazine|accessdate=2008}}</ref> Duthil graduated from the [[University of Rhode Island]]. Rudy Duthil is also one of the founders of [[The Marcus Graham Project]], an organization dedicated to developing leaders in advertising, media and marketing. In 2009 he founded the Results Driven Agency in [[Miami]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Tejada|first=John|title='Boomerang Effect' Event Aims for Media Mentors|url=http://www.adweek.com/news/television/boomerang-effect-event-aims-media-mentors-126023|publisher=ADWEEK|accessdate=March 1, 2011}}</ref>
==Afro-Latino Activist== Rudy Duthil is also known for his activism in the [[Afro-Latin American|Afro-Latino]] movement across the United States. He has published articles such as "Afro-Latino Youth Can Be Gateway For Marketers"<ref>{{cite web|title=Afro-Latino Youth Can Be Gateway for Marketers|url=http://adage.com/article/the-big-tent/afro-latino-youth-gateway-marketers/132479/|publisher=Advertising Age|accessdate=November 12, 2008}}</ref> and "Crossing the Hispanic Color line"<ref>{{cite web|last=Duthil|first=Rudy|title=Crossing the Hispanic Color Line|url=http://adage.com/article/the-big-tent/crossing-hispanic-color-line/125653/|publisher=Advertising Age|accessdate=March 12, 2008}}</ref> on the Big Tent], a multicultural column featured on [[Advertising Age]].
==References== <references />
